name: Battery Park
description: Battery Park City was once the home of container shipping and seaport traffic. In the 1960s, the city reclaimed the land and founded the Battery Park City Authority to own and operate the neighborhood. By the 1970s, it had become a model construction plan for urban residential living.

WHAT TO EXPECT.short: A quiet, manageable neighborhood and an easy commute to work.

THE LIFESTYLE.short: Laid-back, but active. Relaxing strolls along the waterfront or lounging outdoors in one of many public parks.
THE LIFESTYLE.long: There's no lack of wide open spaces in BPC where there are five public parks. These expansive lawns offer a peaceful escape for those who want to nap, read, or tan in a quiet space.

WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.short: Non-stop options for entertainment, shopping or culture.
WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.long: Residents looking for entertainment or culture might be disappointed in Battery Park City's offerings. Although you'll find some stores and restaurants within the World Financial Center's Winter Garden, shopping options are limited in this neighborhood.

THE MARKET.short: Expensive. Large rental complexes and condo buildings with many amenities.
THE MARKET.long: Unlike the rest of New York City, there are no walk-ups or brownstones in Battery Park City. Residents find homes in luxury high-rise condo and rental buildings, most of which are outfitted with concierges, gyms, and parking garages.

YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.short: The immaculate upkeep and peaceful environment of this beautifully-planned neighborhood.
YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.long: Battery Park City is a far departure from the other densely-populated parts of downtown Manhattan. There's a sense of calm that dictates the character of the neighborhood, from the laid-back attitude of residents to the serene stillness of the parks and public spaces.

name: Chelsea
description: Chelsea has consistently served as the setting for iconic pop culture moments with artists like Andy Warhol and Patti Smith living and working in the neighborhood. Now, Chelsea is home to world-famous retrofit architecture and some of the finest art galleries in the city.

WHAT TO EXPECT.short: Great nightlife and an easy commute to anywhere in Manhattan.
WHAT TO EXPECT.long: In Chelsea, everything you need is at your fingertips, especially when it comes to transportation. It’s conveniently located near a number of subway lines, the PATH train, and Penn Station.

THE LIFESTYLE.short: Gallery openings, outdoor lounging, and a new place to discover around every corner.
THE LIFESTYLE.long: Chelsea is home to numerous galleries, with the epicenter of the art scene out on 10th and 11th avenues.

WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.short: A quiet, residential area that caters to a more tranquil lifestyle.
WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.long: In Chelsea, traffic can be loud, and streets are usually crowded with pedestrians during the day.

THE MARKET.short: Newer high-rise buildings, sprawling warehouses, and some steals in post-war walk-ups.
THE MARKET.long: In Chelsea, price points are high for luxury buildings, and slightly more affordable for smaller walk-ups.

YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.short: The class and culture, minus the pretension.
YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.long: Chelsea is a diverse neighborhood with a rich history of social activism and artistic expression. It welcomes neighbors of all kinds to add to its charm.

name: Chinatown
description: As the largest "Chinatown" in the United States, New York's Chinatown has had roots in Eastern traditions since the mid-1800s. An influx of immigrants from Hong Kong and the Fujian Province during the 1900s helped the neighborhood to solidify its identity. Today, Chinatown remains true to its cultural heritage while inviting newcomers to explore and get to know the neighborhood.

WHAT TO EXPECT.short: Affordable downtown living with many commuting options.
WHAT TO EXPECT.long: Chinatown is known for its excellent deals. Shopping or going out to dinner doesn't have to come with a hefty price tag in this neighborhood.

THE LIFESTYLE.short: Exploring diverse cuisines, parks, and understated bars.
THE LIFESTYLE.long: Chinatown is popular among students who frequent the inexpensive bakeries and bubble tea shops around the neighborhood. From mouth-watering roast pork buns to refreshingly cool taro-flavored drinks, Chinatown offers a variety of delicious snacks to choose from.

WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.short: A quiet neighborhood with little street congestion.
WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.long: Chinatown is known for its busy atmosphere and heavy foot traffic. Tourists and vendors pack the sidewalks, making it very congested during the daytime.

THE RENTAL MARKET.short: Primarily walk-up buildings, but a few condo buildings have popped up in recent years.
THE RENTAL MARKET.long: The majority of Chinatown's apartments are walk-ups above restaurants and shops.

YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.short: The immersive cultural experience in a prime downtown location.
YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.long: Chinatown's residents are active in preserving their traditions. One of the most popular destinations for residents and tourists is the Museum of Chinese in America.

name: Civic Center
description: In the 70s, this formerly industrial neighborhood transformed into a haven for the city’s artistic community. Painters, photographers, and sculptors flocked to Tribeca and took over enormous abandoned lofts. Big open spaces became the homes to galleries and studios of some of the most famous New York-based artists.

WHAT TO EXPECT.short: The entertainment perks of living in NYC, but a quieter neighborhood to call home.
WHAT TO EXPECT.long: In Tribeca, you’ll hardly ever encounter congested streets or throngs of people.

THE LIFESTYLE.short: Peaceful strolls along the Hudson River and late (but low-key) nights.
THE LIFESTYLE.long: Tribeca is on a different schedule than other neighborhoods in Manhattan. Shops open a tad later than usual and the area can feel very quaint against the cast-iron architecture.

WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.short: An affordable downtown neighborhood.
WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.long: You’ll be hard pressed to find any below-market deals in Tribeca. The neighborhood is considered one of the most expensive in Manhattan.

THE MARKET.short: Luxury living in lofts and elevator buildings, but at a cost.
THE MARKET.long: High-rise luxury buildings are abundant in Tribeca. The units in Tribeca are big, but residents pay a high price for square-footage. Many have gorgeous waterfront views.

YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.short: The understated elegance, tucked away from busy downtown Manhattan.
YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.long: The uncluttered, simple grace of Tribeca allows for the small details of the neighborhood to shine.

name: East Harlem
description: East Harlem is a living, breathing, collision of vibrant immigrant communities. East Harlem has become a cultural haven, from its title as the birthplace of the salsa and the graffiti movements, to the home of dining landmarks such as Rao’s and Patsy’s Pizzeria.

WHAT TO EXPECT.short: A day-to-day lifestyle steeped in local-feeling routine and community pride.
WHAT TO EXPECT.long: Despite economic and population flux, East Harlem’s present-day education system is home to some of the best and most innovative programs in the city. The primary school trio known as Central Park East (Central Park East I, II, and III, respectively) boast competitive admissions standards and reputations for creative, comprehensive, socially-insightful approaches to learning.

THE LIFESTYLE.short: Casual and familiar. Family-owned restaurants and businesses add to the “know-your-neighbor” vibe.
THE LIFESTYLE.long: No Spanish Harlem stroll would be complete without a sight, smell, or sound of Latin America or the Caribbean islands -- from soulful fusion supper clubs such as Camaradas, to sidewalks lined with carts selling Puerto Rican-born plantain mofongo and hand-blended Mexican “licuado”  smoothies.

WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.short: An upscale nightlife and dining scene or short downtown commutes.
WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.long: Residents looking for an abundance of upscale and trendy culture options might not be satisfied here. The live music and culinary options are among the most authentic in the city, but locals know to find designer labels, organic food markets, and trendy entertainment venues closer to midtown.

THE MARKET.short: Affordable. Walk-ups and brownstone building apartments are most popular, with an increasing number of luxury condo and co-op units on the southern end of the neighborhood.
THE MARKET.long: Low-rise pre-war buildings are available throughout the neighborhood, and make up the majority of options as you move further north. Longtime (and knew residents in the know) also take advantage of a variety of rent-stabilized housing options. Land and space is more affordable in East Harlem and renters can get great value for a large apartment that they might not be able to find elsewhere.

YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.short: The balance of cultural tradition, community-friendly spaces, and sense of growth.
YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.long: Through decades of cultural influx and socio-economic challenges, East Harlem has endured as a home for authentic cultural expression. From progressive after school and public education initiatives to landmark churches and eateries, East Harlem’s rapidly emerging future remains ever-rooted in a monumental past.

name: East Village
description: The East Village has been the center of bohemian lifestyle since the early 1900s when it was a favorite of writers like Allen Ginsberg and artists like Diane Arbus. Its nooks and crannies held bookstores and cafes that inspired and delighted the city’s great thinkers

WHAT TO EXPECT.short: A lively neighborhood with an adventurous spirit that defines downtown living.
WHAT TO EXPECT.long: Quality food abounds in the East Village. Inconspicuous storefronts often conceal some of the best food finds in the city.

THE LIFESTYLE.short: Quiet during the day and packed at night due to the popular culinary and bar scene.
THE LIFESTYLE.long: During the day, the streets are quiet as residents relax outside at places like Tompkins Sq. Park.

WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.short: A quiet, residential area free of street traffic from nightlife outside their doorstep.
WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.long: The neighborhood is fairly expensive, and finding an affordable home can be difficult.

THE RENTAL MARKET.short: Good value in pre-war walkups (especially farther east), but very few doorman or highrise buildings.
THE RENTAL MARKET.long: Pre-war walk-ups are the norm; very few high-rise or doorman buildings exist in the East Village.

YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.short: The creative, gritty, and independent energy of one of the most iconic neighborhoods in Manhattan.
YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.long: Living in the East Village harkens back to a time when Andy Warhol trained his next superstars and Keith Haring learned to paint his iconic pop art.

name: Financial District
description: The Financial District is one of the most historic neighborhoods in Manhattan, and the pulse of our nation’s financial markets. Castle Clinton was America’s first immigration station. Stone Street, the cobblestone alley known for its restaurants, is considered the first paved street in the city, and the Charging Bull statue in front of Bowling Green is one of the city’s most iconic landmarks.

WHAT TO EXPECT.short: Great views, high-rises buildings, and New Yorkers who enjoy the beauty of living on the edge of Manhattan.
WHAT TO EXPECT.long: The Financial District feels like an urban oasis as it sits at the confluence of the Hudson and East River.

THE LIFESTYLE.short: Congested weekdays due to the 9-to-5 hustle, and easygoing nights and weekends along the water.
THE LIFESTYLE.long: During the day, the Financial District is crowded as New Yorkers travel to work at this major commerce center.

WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.short: Active nightlife right outside your door.
WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.long: Energetic nightlife exists in pockets of the area, but most blocks cater to residential or office buildings.

THE MARKET.short: Great value in luxury and high-rise buildings.
THE MARKET.long: With a mix of walk-ups and luxury buildings, FiDi has a wealth of quality real-estate options for a variety of budgets.

YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.short: The architecture: glossy skyscrapers and cobblestone streets set against breathtaking ocean views.
YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.long: In the Financial District, seemingly conflicting architecture combines to create one of the most beautiful skylines in the city. Sleek, towering skyscrapers loom as an impressive reminder of the city’s commercial might.

name: Flatiron
description: In the mid-1990s, the Flatiron District was known for its commercial real estate. Offices, department stores, and big-box retailers dotted the avenues between Union Square and Madison Square Park.

WHAT TO EXPECT.short: A convenient neighborhood close to Union Square and Midtown with plenty of options for public transportation.
WHAT TO EXPECT.long: Flatiron’s central location makes it a convenient neighborhood for commuting to other parts of the city. Union Square is a major hub for public transportation and other subways are within close walking distance.

THE LIFESTYLE.short: Fast-paced during the day and on the weekends, anchored by Union Square and great dining. Relatively quiet and mellow at night.
THE LIFESTYLE.long: By day, Flatiron is defined by the 9-to-5 hustle. The streets are packed with people on their way to work in one of the many office buildings in the neighborhood.

WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.short: A quiet neighborhood free of foot traffic.
WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.long: The streets of Flatiron can become fairly congested during the day and on the weekend. You might want to try and avoid the neighborhood if you’re averse to loud and busy foot and street traffic.

THE MARKET.short: Pricey with very low vacancy rates. Luxury buildings with brand-new amenities, and a few walk-ups buildings.
THE MARKET.long: Because Flatiron is predominantly a commercial neighborhood, there are fewer options for apartments than other places in the city. The neighborhood has a fair number of recently developed luxury buildings on Broadway, Park Avenue, and Fifth Avenue. They often come with all-inclusive gyms, rooftops, and doorman service, but also come with hefty price tags.

YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.short: Historic preservation in the middle of busy Manhattan.
YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.long: Flatiron has grown from an industrial neighborhood centered around one major architectural landmark into a residential area teeming with historic significance and cultural pride.

name: Gramercy
description: In the 1800s, Gramercy Park was designed to house fashionable families. The Roosevelts lived there for decades and enjoyed the area’s exclusive Gramercy Park. Over the years it’s been home to many writers, politicians, artists, and students who enjoy its central location and peaceful atmosphere

WHAT TO EXPECT.short: A small-town feel in a centrally located neighborhood.
WHAT TO EXPECT.long: Gramercy can feel like a secluded, private neighborhood even though it’s located in central Manhattan.

THE LIFESTYLE.short: Low-key days spent outdoors, great cuisine, and a manageable bar scene.
THE LIFESTYLE.long: Day-to-day life in Gramercy is laid-back. With few tourist attractions, the neighborhood is filled with residents looking for a place to relax with privacy.

WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.short: Big-name attractions or non-stop activity.
WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.long: Those who want to be at the center of New York glitz and glam might want to look outside of Gramercy. The mellow neighborhood doesn’t have much to offer in the way of marquee events or hotspots.

THE MARKET.short: Walk-ups and doorman buildings galore, and more affordable options out in Stuy Town.
THE MARKET.long: In Gramercy, you’ll find a number of doorman buildings which offer a considerable amount of space, but at a high cost.

YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.short: The lush greenery on almost every block.
YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.long: Trees, flowers, and small gardens line almost every every street in Gramercy.

name: Greenwich Village
description: For most of the 20th century, Greenwich Village was the center of downtown culture. In the 60s, the Village was the birthplace of the beatnik generation. Allen Ginsberg was known to pop up at Cafe Reggio, while Bob Dylan was a regular performer at Cafe Wha.

WHAT TO EXPECT.short: A bustling, centrally located neighborhood.
WHAT TO EXPECT.long: During the day, the Village moves at a brisk, industrious pace. There’s almost always a consistent level of foot traffic moving throughout the neighborhood.

THE LIFESTYLE.short: Well-balanced. Active days blend into fun, relaxing nights.
THE LIFESTYLE.long: Entertainment never ends in the Village. The neighborhood is a popular meet-up spot for get togethers amongst friends.

WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.short: A neighborhood that's far removed from typical NYC to-and-fro.
WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.long: Greenwich Village rarely ever gets excessively congested, but streets are almost never completely quiet, either.

THE MARKET.short: Generally expensive, but plenty of options across a diverse blend of walk-ups, brownstones, and doorman buildings.
THE MARKET.long: Some residents might find pre-war walk-ups on side streets, but will often pay for the idyllic location rather than the space.

YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.short: The communal culture of this down-to-earth, embracing neighborhood.
YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.long: Throughout it’s history, Greenwich Village has always been a breeding ground for important, influential New Yorkers. Maybe that’s why it feels like with just the right amount of persistence...

name: Harlem
description: Harlem is known as an important touchpoint of American jazz, literature, and civil rights history. And for good reason: major streets like Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Blvd., Malcolm X Blvd., and Martin Luther King Jr. Blvd. pay homage to civil rights leaders that actually walked those passageways. Meanwhile, venues such as The Apollo Theater, Hotel Theresa, and Sylvia’s Restaurant stand as iconic landmarks frequented by both history buffs and culture seekers alike.

WHAT TO EXPECT.short: A quiet residential scene in the midst of a bustling culture hub.
WHAT TO EXPECT.long: Unlike many other tourist and commuter-friendly Manhattan neighborhoods, life in Harlem can feel as quiet as it does connected to the rest of the city.

THE LIFESTYLE.short: Soulful. A community-oriented atmosphere defined by music, food and cultural events.
THE LIFESTYLE.long: Life in Harlem is as rooted in cultural tradition as is it energized and diverse. In the last decade, restaurants like Red Rooster, Harlem Tavern, and Harlem Shake have reinvented a dining scene traditionally defined by soul food icons like Sylvia’s and Amy Ruth’s.

WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.short: A bar-driven, late night party scene.
WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.long: In Harlem, weekend dining and coffee culture are as significant as the nightlife scene. Live jazz brunches at venues like Harlem Tavern and Ginny’s Supper Club attract diners with an inventive cocktail menu and music mix.

THE MARKET.short: Affordable nineteenth century apartments and brownstones are becoming more competitive, and new developments are popping up throughout the neighborhood.
THE MARKET.long: Charming, historic brownstones and walk-ups are relatively abundant, especially from 125th to 145th streets.

YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.short: The rich history and widespread sense of community.
YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.long: Legendary music and food venues are only a few reasons to love life here. Residents of all ages and stages revel in the equal sense of historical significance and current cultural cachet.

name: Hell's Kitchen
description: Named for the notorious 19th century motorcycle gang, “Hell’s Kitchen” was once a part of town where few New Yorkers thought to live. Its gritty reputation and far-west location kept it under the radar.  But today’s Hell’s Kitchen is a far cry from the image its name evokes.  In the past ten years, developers and small business owners have planted roots in this up-and-coming neighborhood.

WHAT TO EXPECT.short: A neighborhood that has a little bit of everything: culture, entertainment, and convenience.
WHAT TO EXPECT.long: In Hell’s Kitchen, the streets are saturated with local business across a spectrum of categories. Neighborhood-owned bakeries, bodegas, and bistros make it feel like a real community.

THE LIFESTYLE.short: Decidedly unpretentious: bustling streets, eclectic restaurants, and a welcoming atmosphere.
THE LIFESTYLE.long: In Hell’s Kitchen the streets always have a steady buzz about them, giving an energetic and spirited feel to the neighborhood.

WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.short: Anyone who hopes to escape the loud noise or congestion of Midtown.
WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.long: Depending on which part of Hell’s Kitchen you choose, you might have to become accustomed to the noise of thise Midtown neighborhoods. Port Authority and Times Square are nearby, which makes for tourists and travelers at all hours of the day.

THE MARKET.short: Mostly affordable walkups and doorman buildings, and newer luxury-high rise buildings.
THE MARKET.long: In Hell’s Kitchen zoning laws cap most buildings in the neighborhood to six stories, so homes tend to be in walk-ups, townhouses or brownstones.

YOU’LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.short: The way this up-and-coming neighborhood continues to evolve while staying close to its roots.
YOU’LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.long: Hell’s Kitchen has come a long way from its rough-and-tumble history. New developments and businesses are springing up throughout the neighborhood, and extending the skyline onward and upward.

name: Kips Bay
description: In the early 1900s, Murray Hill was known as an upscale neighborhood with gorgeous brownstones marked with old NYC charm. Since then, the neighborhood has gotten younger and more affordable with an active nightlife scene and an influx of NYC transplants.

WHAT TO EXPECT.short: A lively yet manageable neighborhood close to work in Midtown.
WHAT TO EXPECT.long: Murray Hill’s location makes it an ideal neighborhood for many professionals that work in Midtown. For many commuters, the proximity to Grand Central Station is especially convenient.

THE LIFESTYLE.short: Walks along the East River, diverse and affordable dining, and a spirited bar scene.
THE LIFESTYLE.long: During the day, Murray Hill can feel like a sleepy village with quiet, tranquil streets.

WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.short: Easy access to the pulse of the NYC arts and culture scene.
WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.long: Murray Hill isn’t considered the center of the fast, glamorous NYC lifestyle. Instead, the neighborhood is a decidedly no-frills, down-to-earth pocket of the city.

THE MARKET.short: Very reasonable. You can find great deals for spacious apartments in high-rise buildings.
THE MARKET.long: In Murray Hill you’ll find brownstones, townhouses, and a number of spacious mid-rise condo buildings.

YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.short: The welcoming, down-to-earth energy in this convenient and comfortable neighborhood.
YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.long: Murray Hill is a neighborhood that prides itself on bringing a refreshing simplicity to living life in the city.

name: Little Italy
description: Little Italy got its name back in the early 1900s when thousands of Italian immigrants moved into the small neighborhood. Since then, many of the area's Italian-American residents have relocated to other Italian enclaves like East Harlem, the Bronx, and Staten Island. Still, their original legacy remains, and is woven into the fabric of this culturally distinct pocket of lower Manhattan.

WHAT TO EXPECT.short: A historically rich neighborhood with old-world European charm.
WHAT TO EXPECT.long: Built upon by the dedicated efforts of its first immigrants, many of Little Italy's businesses are inspired by its European counterparts. Current residents favor the nostalgia-induced environment that evokes memories of life in the 1920s with trattoria-lined streets and signs written in Italian.

THE LIFESTYLE.short: Great food and good times. Culinary immersion in authentic Italian restaurants, indulging at meat and cheese shops, and browsing vintage boutiques.
THE LIFESTYLE.long: In Little Italy, dining is the main attraction. Preparation for the busy day ahead begins early when restaurant staffs set up outdoor seating and make plans for accommodating the steady stream of customers throughout the day.

WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.short: A quiet neighborhood with parks and open spaces.
WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.long: As one of the most well-known neighborhoods in New York, the area experiences a steady flow of foot traffic from neighbors and visitors at all times of the day. Residents who prefer quiet, empty streets might want to look outside of Little Italy,

THE MARKET.short: Competitive. Co-op buildings and walk-ups have low turnover rates and prices are consistently on the rise.
THE MARKET.long: Most residential buildings in the neighborhood are walk-up apartments above restaurants or storefronts.

YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.short: Italian cultural charm set in downtown Manhattan.
YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.long: Visitors of Little Italy come to experience the Italian culture brought from overseas. Tourists and residents alike enjoy freshly rolled cigars and authentic gelato, all reminders of the neighborhood's Italian roots.

name: Lower East Side
description: In the nineteenth and early twentieth century, the Lower East Side was known as a hub for European immigrants, as well as the center of Jewish life in New York City.

WHAT TO EXPECT.short: Some of the best nightlife, dining, and entertainment in Manhattan.
WHAT TO EXPECT.long: In large part due to a booming bar and club scene, the Lower East Side is a great choice for Manhattanites who want to have the nightlife scene right outside their doorstep.

THE LIFESTYLE.short: Lounge during the day, dine at dusk, and party all night.
THE LIFESTYLE.long: During the day, the Lower East Side is relatively quiet.

WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.short: A quiet, residential neighborhood close to transportation.
WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.long: Couples who choose to raise children here might be thrown by the noise levels in the heart of the Lower East Side near Delancey Street.

THE MARKET.short: Affordable. Mainly pre-war walk-ups, but there are a few newer luxury high-rise buildings.
THE MARKET.long: A handful of modern luxury high-rises have sprung up in recent years, but most apartments are pre-war walk-ups.

YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.short: The free-spirit tradition of this diverse, welcoming community.
YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.long: Even though the Lower East Side is synonymous with the party scene, those who live in the neighborhood love it for its well-worn, homely touches of community.

name: Midtown
description: Midtown East is the New York City that everyone around the world knows from TV shows and postcards.  Home to iconic skyscrapers like the Chrysler Building, Rockefeller Center, and United Nations Headquarters, this timeless, architecturally important neighborhood is at the heart of it all, while its serene, tree-lined cross streets house some of Manhattan’s most prestigious and sought-after residential buildings.

WHAT TO EXPECT.short: A convenient neighborhood in the center of Manhattan that provides A-list cultural attractions and easy access to anywhere in the city.
WHAT TO EXPECT.long: From the world-renowned shopping of Fifth Avenue to people-watching at Rockefeller Center, Midtown East is filled to the brim with picture-postcard New York City moments.

THE LIFESTYLE.short: Vibrant and bustling, with all the best of Manhattan living mere steps from your front door.
THE LIFESTYLE.long: There’s always something happening here. Bryant Park is a popular hub in Midtown no matter the time of year. During the summer, people gather for yoga classes, outdoor movie screenings, and picnics. Come winter, neighbors spend afternoons ice skating here. It's perhaps most used during the day as a great way for those that work in the area to take a much needed break from the work day.

WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.short: The non-stop party atmosphere of  trendy Downtown neighborhoods.
WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.long: Midtown East isn’t trying to compete with the Lower East Side or Brooklyn to be the coolest kid on the block. The scene here is a bit more refined; with the Museum of Modern Art, the Morgan Library, and the main branch of the New York Public Library, you’ll never be at a loss for top-tier cultural attractions. Michelin-starred eateries like Daniel and The Modern are plentiful.

THE MARKET.short: A mix of new development luxury condos and prestigious co-ops, plus more affordable walk-up rentals.
THE MARKET.long: With an array of of stately prewar towers and sleek  full-service high-rises, there are lots of options in Midtown East, particularly at the higher end of the market. Classic townhouses provide even more options for spacious luxury homes. Beyond the luxury condo and coop buildings, renters will find plenty of options, particularly in the Turtle Bay section east of Lexington Avenue.

YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.short: The city skyline and waterfront vistas, best seen from above.
YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.long: While Midtown East is best known for being in the center of everything, for many residents the prime appeal is the tranquil setting along the East River. Many high-rise towers offer views stretching out over the river to Queens, up to the Ed Koch Queensboro Bridge, and across the skyline of Midtown Manhattan. A popular amenity in the neighborhood is a rooftop deck offering sweeping views.

name: Murray Hill
description: In the early 1900s, Murray Hill was known as an upscale neighborhood with gorgeous brownstones marked with old NYC charm. Since then, the neighborhood has gotten younger and more affordable with an active nightlife scene and an influx of NYC transplants.

WHAT TO EXPECT.short: A lively yet manageable neighborhood close to work in Midtown.
WHAT TO EXPECT.long: Murray Hill’s location makes it an ideal neighborhood for many professionals that work in Midtown. For many commuters, the proximity to Grand Central Station is especially convenient.

THE LIFESTYLE.short: Walks along the East River, diverse and affordable dining, and a spirited bar scene.
THE LIFESTYLE.long: During the day, Murray Hill can feel like a sleepy village with quiet, tranquil streets.

WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.short: Easy access to the pulse of the NYC arts and culture scene.
WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.long: Murray Hill isn’t considered the center of the fast, glamorous NYC lifestyle. Instead, the neighborhood is a decidedly no-frills, down-to-earth pocket of the city.

THE MARKET.short: Very reasonable. You can find great deals for spacious apartments in high-rise buildings.
THE MARKET.long: In Murray Hill you’ll find brownstones, townhouses, and a number of spacious mid-rise condo buildings.

YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.short: The welcoming, down-to-earth energy in this convenient and comfortable neighborhood.
YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.long: Murray Hill is a neighborhood that prides itself on bringing a refreshing simplicity to living life in the city.

name: NoHo
description: Noho, short for North of Houston, has a reputation of being one of the most in-demand neighborhoods in New York City. The area’s long-standing commercial history from 1850 to the early 1900’s helped shape the neighborhood’s striking architectural features, along with influential residents such as the Delanos and Peter Cooper. Formerly known as the “Warehouse District,” Noho’s vintage store-and-loft buildings have since been modernized to suit a more fashion-forward and edgy downtown styling.

WHAT TO EXPECT.short: All of the benefits of living downtown, but also value a quick and easy commute to other parts of the city.
WHAT TO EXPECT.long: Bounded by Broadway and Bowery, Noho maintains a six-block escape for those looking to get out of the crowds of nearby neighborhoods like Soho, Greenwich Village, or the East Village.

THE LIFESTYLE.short: Laid-back but constantly stimulating. Days are spent lounging at coffee shops or browsing boutiques, and nights are spent at sleek lounges and art house theaters.
THE LIFESTYLE.long: Noho’s entertainment and culture scene is heavily influenced by a history of having artists-in-residence. Colonnade Row is a perfect example of a residential-cultural space, with the Astor Place Theater serving as the original home of the acclaimed Blue Man Group and other off-Broadway shows.

WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.short: A quiet neighborhood with plenty of green space.
WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.long: There are almost no public parks and green spaces in this tiny, landlocked neighborhood. Those who want homes surrounded by nature might want to look elsewhere.

THE MARKET.short: Pricey. New luxury buildings near Bowery and walk-ups on side streets are some of the most highly sought-after in the downtown market.
THE MARKET.long: Noho has a relatively diverse mix of real-estate options, albeit in low quantities. Lofts and walk-ups lend themselves to a classic old-New York feel throughout the neighborhood.

YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.short: The unique architectural design and rich artistic history.
YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.long: Noho is known for its distinctive architectural style. Whether it’s Classical or Renaissance-inspired, Noho displays an eclectic mix of facades around every corner.

name: Nolita
description: Nolita, which stands for North of Little Italy, sits at the nexus of a number of popular downtown neighborhoods: Soho, Noho, the Lower East Side, and Little Italy. Originally filled with Italian slaughterhouses, bakeries, and churches, Nolita received its old-world character from first-time residents in the 1770s.

WHAT TO EXPECT.short: A neighborhood that combines downtown lifestyle with a cozy, quaint vibe.
WHAT TO EXPECT.long: Nolita feels like an intimate neighborhood where you can go to escape the crowds of SoHo or tourists passing through Little Italy to experience a quiet moment of your own.

THE LIFESTYLE.short: Outdoor lounging on picturesque streets, discovering hidden finds at chic boutiques and art galleries, and dinner and drinks that extend late into the night.
THE LIFESTYLE.long: Before noon, Nolita looks like the background of a film set in New York.

WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.short: Wide open spaces with easy access to parks and greenspace.
WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.long: In this land-locked neighborhood, finding a spot of green space can be difficult.

THE MARKET.short: Competitive. Manicured pre-war walk-ups with low turnover rates.
THE MARKET.long: In a neighborhood that's only four blocks wide, apartments can be hard to find. Turnover rates are low because many residents know that if they leave Nolita, it might be difficult to come back.

YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.short: The effortlessly cool charm of this small but vibrant neighborhood.
YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.long: The streets of Nolita look like outdoor galleries where brick walls become a colorful backdrop for passerbys.

name: SoHo
description: Soho has a long history of inspiring New York’s creative communities. The same lofts that used to house manufacturing factories in the 1950s are now home to photo studios, fashion houses, and art galleries.

WHAT TO EXPECT.short: A creative vibe established by the neighborhood’s resident artists and the pulse of downtown NYC at your fingertips.
WHAT TO EXPECT.long: Soho is centrally located downtown making for an easy walk (or ride) around the city.

THE LIFESTYLE.short: A neighborhood that never slows down with endless options to explore for shopping, dining, and entertainment.
THE LIFESTYLE.long: In Soho you'll find flagship retailers, eclectic boutiques, and homespun knick-knacks.

WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.short: Substantial indoor space or easily accessible outdoor space.
WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.long: Soho can get fairly crowded: Broadway draws droves of shoppers daily.

THE MARKET.short: High price points and low vacancies.
THE MARKET.long: In Soho, spaces are tight and price tags high. Most buildings are walk-ups or luxury co-ops.

YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.short: Quaint cobblestone side streets, cast-iron facades, and the bohemian energy.
YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.long: The cobblestone side streets are a peaceful respite from the well-travelled main streets.

name: Theater District
description: The Theater District has undergone serious transformation over the last century. During the early 20th century, the area was known as home to history-making families such as the the Astors and the Rockefellers, and was officially named for the New York Times original headquarters on the square in 1903. The post-Depression era saw an influx of downtown-bred music, dance, and drama venues (hence, the term “Theater District”), and a mid-century decline followed by a city-led commercial rebrand and tourist boom. Today’s Theater District is a hub for awe-inspiring happenings around every corner.

WHAT TO EXPECT.short: An energetic, commuter-friendly neighborhood surrounded by iconic NYC streets and scenery.
WHAT TO EXPECT.long: For those that want to live and play at “the center of it all”, there’s no more stimulating  place than the Theater District, often also referred to as Midtown West.

THE LIFESTYLE.short: High-energy days and nights, destination entertainment venues, and an approachable (and always packed) drinking and dining scene.
THE LIFESTYLE.long: Manhattan owes much of its fast-paced cultural reputation to the sights and sounds that you’ll only find in the Theater District. Street artists, souvenir carts, and a constant flow of foot traffic keeps the neighborhood on a round-the-clock cycle of commerce, culture, and fun-seeking.

WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.short: A quiet neighborhood vibe or extensive green space.
WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.long: Taxis and tourist destinations dominate the Theater District scene. Those seeking more greenery and room to spread out and have fun should look west to the Hell’s Kitchen waterfront or the less congested streets of Midtown East.

THE MARKET.short: Competitively priced. Modern doorman buildings become more expensive as you move further north toward Central Park South.
THE MARKET.long: Newcomers are pleasantly surprised to find competitively priced studio apartments and penthouses in the heart of Times Square.

YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.short: Endless people-watching and entertainment options.
YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.long: Larger-than-life commercial outposts and talent spanning Broadway and beyond attract visitors and residents from all walks of life and corners of the globe.

name: TriBeCa
description: In the 70s, this formerly industrial neighborhood transformed into a haven for the city’s artistic community. Painters, photographers, and sculptors flocked to Tribeca and took over enormous abandoned lofts. Big open spaces became the homes to galleries and studios of some of the most famous New York-based artists.

WHAT TO EXPECT.short: The entertainment perks of living in NYC, but a quieter neighborhood to call home.
WHAT TO EXPECT.long: In Tribeca, you’ll hardly ever encounter congested streets or throngs of people.

THE LIFESTYLE.short: Peaceful strolls along the Hudson River and late (but low-key) nights.
THE LIFESTYLE.long: Tribeca is on a different schedule than other neighborhoods in Manhattan. Shops open a tad later than usual and the area can feel very quaint against the cast-iron architecture.

WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.short: An affordable downtown neighborhood.
WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.long: You’ll be hard pressed to find any below-market deals in Tribeca. The neighborhood is considered one of the most expensive in Manhattan.

THE MARKET.short: Luxury living in lofts and elevator buildings, but at a cost.
THE MARKET.long: High-rise luxury buildings are abundant in Tribeca. The units in Tribeca are big, but residents pay a high price for square-footage. Many have gorgeous waterfront views.

YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.short: The understated elegance, tucked away from busy downtown Manhattan.
YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.long: The uncluttered, simple grace of Tribeca allows for the small details of the neighborhood to shine.

name: Upper East Side
description: Some of America’s most famous families have made their homes on the Upper East Side: the Roosevelts, Kennedys, Rockefellers, and Carnegies were all real-estate pioneers in the early 1900s and developed the neighborhood into a beautiful and posh place to live.

WHAT TO EXPECT.short: An affordable and spacious apartment for those who require it.
WHAT TO EXPECT.long: The Upper East Side moves at a slower, more relaxed paced than other neighborhoods in Manhattan.

THE LIFESTYLE.short: Playtime in Central Park, constant culture at your fingertips, and a fun and accessible nightlife.
THE LIFESTYLE.long: Central Park becomes your playground when you live on the Upper East Side.

WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.short: Easy access to the West side.
WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.long: Commuters who work on the Upper West Side or in Midtown West may find the Upper East Side inconvenient. Although the neighborhood has become much more accessible in recent years, thanks to the 2nd Avenue and Q train extensions, traveling across the park remains difficult.

THE MARKET.short: Reasonable apartments for diverse budgets, and expansive townhouses for a higher cost.
THE MARKET.long: The Upper East Side real-estate is the stuff of legends, especially townhouses and luxury doorman buildings on Fifth, Madison and Park Avenue.

YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.short: Staying close to home - everything you need is in this sprawling, self-contained Manhattan retreat.
YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.long: Although the Upper East Side can feel far away from the rest of the city, you’ll be so taken by the beauty of this quiet, lush neighborhood that you probably won’t mind.

name: Upper West Side
description: The Upper West Side has a longstanding reputation for attracting the culturally-aware. Artists, professors, filmmakers, and writers made their homes on the Upper West Side and helped it develop into an urban oasis for intellectual curiosity.

WHAT TO EXPECT.short: A sprawling artistic neighborhood with easy access to greenspace.
WHAT TO EXPECT.long: There’s no lack of greenery on the Upper West Side with both Central Park and Riverside Park. In Central Park, Strawberry Fields, the Great Lawn, and Sheep Meadow are luxurious during the spring.

THE LIFESTYLE.short: Casual strolls along quiet streets and plenty of opportunities to indulge in your cultural curiosity
THE LIFESTYLE.long: In the Upper West Side, many blocks feel like quiet, small-town neighborhoods.

WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.short: Dusk-till-dawn nightlife right outside of your doorstep. The entertainment scene is centered around relaxed bars and restaurants.
WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.long: The Upper West Side isn’t considered a destination for hardcore partiers. A row of bars on Amsterdam Avenue is popular  for sporting events and low-key nights out.

THE MARKET.short: Pricey high-rises and townhouses, but buildings farther north can be more affordable.
THE MARKET.long: The Upper West Side has a large number of condo, co-ops and high-rise buildings.

YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.short: The intimate and inviting spirit of the neighborhood.
YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.long: Cozy brick apartment buildings and tree-lined streets give the neighborhood an intimate and friendly vibe, like a childhood home imported to NYC.

name: West Village
description: The West Village has been the center of bohemian lifestyle since the early 1900s when it was a favorite of writers like Allen Ginsberg and artists like Diane Arbus.  Its nooks and crannies held bookstores and cafes that inspired and delighted the city’s great thinkers.

WHAT TO EXPECT.short: Those who want a neighborhood that’s mellow and laid-back, but never dull.
WHAT TO EXPECT.long: The West Village is filled with picturesque blocks reminiscent of photos from an old NYC scrapbook.

THE LIFESTYLE.short: Lazy strolls along the tree-lined streets and stylish cafes at every criss-crossed corner.
THE LIFESTYLE.long: Cobblestone streets and greenery make the West Village feel like an intimate, communal neighborhood.

WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.short: Affordable housing, nightlife, and restaurants.
WHAT NOT TO EXPECT.long: The neighborhood is fairly expensive, and finding an affordable home can be difficult.

THE MARKET.short: Brownstones, mid-rise co-ops, and walkups. Low vacancy rates lead to a high demand for inventory.
THE MARKET.long: The West Village is known for its stunning brownstones, co-ops, and condos.

YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.short: The small-town European vibe.
YOU'LL FALL IN LOVE WITH.long: You’ll fall in love with the effortless grace of the West Village and its residents - especially those on four legs.
